Description:
The artist has created an idealized image of a beautiful young woman with jewelry and long flowing hair. She is surrounded by a scroll that translates: "As long as I live, I will love you, and after your death my one humble desire is to be united with you. I am left at your mercy." Such a melancholic and stylized declaration of love was characteristic of courtly society and speaks of the power of beauty to enamor the beholder.

Painted in cobalt blue and gold-colored luster, the plate utilizes the color scheme that Italian painters of maiolica knew from Hispano-Moresque earthenware.
Inscriptions: [Transcription] On the front, in a scroll above the woman’s head: PER / FIC / HE • VIVO / IT / AM / ERO • EDAPVO • MOTE • SIPVSIVEL • SIA•LECO / RE • TE / LAS / CIO ITV / A • BAL / IA ; [Translation] As long as I live, I will love you, and after your death my one humble desire is to be united with you. I am left at your mercy.
Medium: earthenware with tin glaze (maiolica) and luster decoration

MuseumLocation.DisplayCurrentLocation: Charles Street: Third Floor: Renaissance Ceramics

Provenance: Henry Walters, Baltimore [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Lustered dish with a female figure
